title.value: Using Confounded Data in Latent Model-Based Reinforcement Learning
title.justification: This is the title provided in the paper's header.
title.quote: Using Confounded Data in Latent Model-Based Reinforcement Learning

extractions.description: This paper addresses the issue of confounding in offline reinforcement learning (RL). It proposes a method to exploit confounded offline data in model-based RL to enhance the sample-efficiency of an interactive agent that collects and learns from online, unconfounded data. The method leverages do-calculus to treat model-based RL as a causal inference problem and introduces a generic method for learning a causal transition model that accounts for confounding through a hidden latent variable. The paper demonstrates the method's effectiveness through synthetic experiments.

type.justification: The paper presents practical experiments to validate the proposed method.
type.quote: We showcase our method on a series of synthetic experiments.

name.justification: The research focuses on issues inherent in reinforcement learning, specifically offline and model-based reinforcement learning.
name.quote: bridging the gap between the fields of RL and causality.

name.justification: The method proposed focuses on model-based reinforcement learning.
name.quote: we propose a safe method to exploit confounded offline data in model-based RL, which improves the sample-efficiency of an interactive agent.

name.justification: The approach utilizes causal inference principles, specifically do-calculus, to address the problem.
name.quote: we import ideas from the well-established framework of do-calculus to express model-based RL as a causal inference problem.

name.justification: The method presented in the paper is referred to as a latent model-based RL method.
name.quote: Then, we propose a generic method for learning a causal transition model from offline and online data, which captures and corrects the confounding effect using a hidden latent variable.

is_contributed.justification: The paper contributes this method as its central proposition.
is_contributed.quote: Then, we propose a generic method for learning a causal transition model from offline and online data, which captures and corrects the confounding effect using a hidden latent variable.

is_executed.justification: The model's performance was demonstrated in synthetic experiments.
is_executed.quote: We illustrate the effectiveness of our method with a practical implementation for the tabular setting, and three experiments on synthetic toy problems.

is_compared.justification: The model was compared against other baselines in the experiments.
is_compared.quote: We compare our augmented method against two baselines: no obs which discards the observational dataset, and naive which naively combines observational and interventional data as if there was no confounding.

referenced_paper_title.value: Using Confounded Data in Latent Model-Based Reinforcement Learning
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the title of the current paper, indicating that it is the main model introduced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Then, we propose a generic method for learning a causal transition model from offline and online data, which captures and corrects the confounding effect using a hidden latent variable.

name.justification: This is a synthetic POMDP used for evaluating the proposed method.
name.quote: Tiger is a classic small-scale POMDP from Cassandra et al. [4] with |S| = 6 hidden states and time horizon T = 10.

referenced_paper_title.value: Acting optimally in partially observable stochastic domains
referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper introduces the Tiger problem used in this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Tiger is a classic small-scale POMDP from Cassandra et al. [4] with |S| = 6 hidden states and time horizon T = 10.

name.justification: This is another synthetic POMDP used for evaluating the proposed method.
name.quote: Hidden treasures is a 3x3 grid-world problem inspired from Sutton et al. [37], with |S| = 36 hidden states and a time horizon T = 10.

referenced_paper_title.value: Between MDPs and Semi-MDPs: A Framework for Temporal Abstraction in Reinforcement Learning
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper provides the basis for the Hidden Treasures problem used in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Hidden treasures is a 3x3 grid-world problem inspired from Sutton et al. [37], with |S| = 36 hidden states and a time horizon T = 10.

name.justification: This is another synthetic POMDP used for evaluating the proposed method.
name.quote: Sloppy dark room is a 5x5 grid-world inspired from Alt et al. [1], with |S| = 21 hidden states and a time horizon T = 30.

referenced_paper_title.value: POMDPs in continuous time and discrete spaces
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper provides the basis for Sloppy Dark Room used in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Sloppy dark room is a 5x5 grid-world inspired from Alt et al. [1], with |S| = 21 hidden states and a time horizon T = 30.

name.justification: PyTorch is mentioned as the primary library used for model training.
name.quote: The training was done using the Adam optimizer implemented in PyTorch.

referenced_paper_title.value: Adam: A Method for Stochastic Optimization
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper referencing Adam is the original paper introducing the optimizer, which is part of PyTorch's library.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The training was done using the Adam optimizer implemented in PyTorch.
